15. “Ah” (said the king), you who are
our beloved friend, should you not permit
marriage between your Wife
and my Son, who alone (as you know)
will inherit our Kingdom and Crown?”
“You” (said the other) “who are his loving Father,
if he loved Stratonice one could imagine
you would not give her to him.”

16. “Oh friend, as my God grants me grace,
if any Person had such great virtue
that I would transfer my Wife
to this lover, for the sake of my Son’s health
so that he could live in gilded youth,
I would gladly, offer her with love and joy,
and also my entire kingdom,” was the King’s reply,
with a heart full of feeling and eyes full of tears.

17. Then the Master boldly grasped his right hand,
saying, “Be wise and closely watch
the prosperity of your house this season,
and you will need my help no further.
You are this Lovers’ Father, and husband to his beloved,
And considering you are King, you must
take action as you think best.”
At once he [the king] gathered his people in council.

18. The King’s decision proceeded, with no opposition
at the discretion of Friends or Princes:
For his Fatherly love was so effective
that she who was first his Wife became his Daughter-in-law.
The Son was rid of his heartbreaking agony
and further, gained a number of Provinces.
This is described in Rhyme from the prose of Plutarch
To point out how love reveals itself through blushes.
right-middleThe wondrous love of Seleucus for his Son.

19. There is a Proverb to keep in mind now:
whither pain, there goes the hand; whither love, there goes the eye.
This was from both, for if the head or shin
Feels pain, the hand will go there.
And the gaze will persevere and go
where the heart wills and allows it,
following the beloved as they go here and there,
just as Clytie did with the Sun’s rays.
right-middleA Proverb: whither love, there the eye: for the eye is the heart’s messenger.
